verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 1:1
verses.text: Dialogue of Justin, Philosopher and Martyr, with Trypho, a Jew   Chapter 1 — Introduction.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 1:2
verses.text: While I was going about one morning in the walks of the Xystus, a certain man, with others in his company, having met me, and said, "Hail, O philosopher!" And immediately after saying this, he turned round and walked along with me; his friends likewise followed him.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 1:3
verses.text: And I in turn having addressed him, said, "What is there important?"  And he replied, "I was instructed," says he "by Corinthus the Socratic in Argos, that I ought not to despise or treat with indifference those who array themselves in this dress but to show them all kindness, and to associate with them, as perhaps some advantage would spring from the intercourse either to some such man or to myself.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 1:4
verses.text: It is good, moreover, for both, if either the one or the other be benefited.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 1:5
verses.text: On this account, therefore, whenever I see any one in such costume, I gladly approach him, and now, for the same reason, have I willingly accosted you; and these accompany me, in the expectation of hearing for themselves something profitable from you".

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 1:6
verses.text: "But who are you, most excellent man?" So I replied to him in jest.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 1:7
verses.text: Then he told me frankly both his name and his family.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 1:8
verses.text: "Trypho," says he, "I am called; and I am a Hebrew of the circumcision, and having escaped from the war lately carried on there I am spending my days in Greece, and chiefly at Corinth".

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 1:9
verses.text: "And in what," said I, "would you be profited by philosophy so much as by your own lawgiver and the prophets?"  "Why not?" he replied.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 1:10
verses.text: "Do not the philosophers turn every discourse on God? and do not questions continually arise to them about His unity and providence? Is not this truly the duty of philosophy, to investigate the Deity?"  "Assuredly," said I, "so we too have believed.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 1:11
verses.text: But the most have not taken thought of this whether there be one or more gods, and whether they have a regard for each one of us or no, as if this knowledge contributed nothing to our happiness; nay, they moreover attempt to persuade us that God takes care of the universe with its genera and species, but not of me and you, and each individually, since otherwise we would surely not need to pray to Him night and day.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 1:12
verses.text: But it is not difficult to understand the upshot of this; for fearlessness and license in speaking result to such as maintain these opinions, doing and saying whatever they choose, neither dreading punishment nor hoping for any benefit from God.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 1:13
verses.text: For how could they? They affirm that the same things shall always happen; and, further, that I and you shall again live in like manner, having become neither better men nor worse.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 1:14
verses.text: But there are some others, who, having supposed the soul to be immortal and immaterial, believe that though they have committed evil they will not suffer punishment (for that which is immaterial is insensible), and that the soul, in consequence of its immortality, needs nothing from God".

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 1:15
verses.text: And he, smiling gently, said, "Tell us your opinion of these matters, and what idea you entertain respecting God, and what your philosophy is".

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 2:1
verses.text: Chapter 2 — Justin describes his studies in philosophy.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 2:2
verses.text: "I will tell you," said I, "what seems to me; for philosophy is, in fact, the greatest possession, and most honourable before God, to whom it leads us and alone commends us; and these are truly holy men who have bestowed attention on philosophy.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 2:3
verses.text: What philosophy is, however, and the reason why it has been sent down to men, have escaped the observation of most; for there would be neither Platonists, nor Stoics, nor Peripatetics, nor Theoretics, nor Pythagoreans, this knowledge being one.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 2:4
verses.text: I wish to tell you why it has become many-headed.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 2:5
verses.text: It has happened that those who first handled it  i-e:, philosophy, and who were therefore esteemed illustrious men, were succeeded by those who made no investigations concerning truth, but only admired the perseverance and self-discipline of the former, as well as the novelty of the doctrines; and each thought that to be true which he learned from his teacher: then, moreover, those latter persons handed down to their successors such things, and others similar to them; and this system was called by the name of him who was styled the father of the doctrine.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 2:6
verses.text: Being at first desirous of personally conversing with one of these men, I surrendered myself to a certain Stoic; and having spent a considerable time with him, when I had not acquired any further knowledge of God (for he did not know himself, and said such instruction was unnecessary), I left him and betook myself to another, who was called a Peripatetic, and as he fancied, shrewd.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 2:7
verses.text: And this man, after having entertained me for the first few days, requested me to settle the fee, in order that our intercourse might not be unprofitable.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 2:8
verses.text: Him, too, for this reason I abandoned, believing him to be no philosopher at all.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 2:9
verses.text: But when my soul was eagerly desirous to hear the peculiar and choice philosophy, I came to a Pythagorean, very celebrated—a man who thought much of his own wisdom.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 2:10
verses.text: And then, when I had an interview with him, willing to become his hearer and disciple, he said, 'What then? Are you acquainted with music, astronomy, and geometry? Do you expect to perceive any of those things which conduce to a happy life, if you have not been first informed on those points which wean the soul from sensible objects, and render it fitted for objects which appertain to the mind, so that it can contemplate that which is honourable in its essence and that which is good in its essence?' Having commended many of these branches of learning, and telling me that they were necessary, he dismissed me when I confessed to him my ignorance.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 2:11
verses.text: Accordingly I took it rather impatiently, as was to be expected when I failed in my hope, the more so because I deemed the man had some knowledge; but reflecting again on the space of time during which I would have to linger over those branches of learning, I was not able to endure longer procrastination.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 2:12
verses.text: In my helpless condition it occurred to me to have a meeting with the Platonists, for their fame was great.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 2:13
verses.text: I thereupon spent as much of my time as possible with one who had lately settled in our city,—a sagacious man, holding a high position among the Platonists,—and I progressed, and made the greatest improvements daily.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 2:14
verses.text: And the perception of immaterial things quite overpowered me, and the contemplation of ideas furnished my mind with wings, so that in a little while I supposed that I had become wise; and such was my stupidity, I expected forthwith to look upon God, for this is the end of Plato's philosophy.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 3:1
verses.text: Chapter 3 — Justin narrates the manner of his conversion.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 3:2
verses.text: "And while I was thus disposed, when I wished at one period to be filled with great quietness, and to shun the path of men, I used to go into a certain field not far from the sea.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 3:3
verses.text: And when I was near that spot one day, which having reached I purposed to be by myself, a certain old man, by no means contemptible in appearance, exhibiting meek and venerable manners, followed me at a little distance.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 3:4
verses.text: And when I turned round to him, having halted, I fixed my eyes rather keenly on him.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 3:5
verses.text: "And he said, 'Do you know me?'  "I replied in the negative.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 3:6
verses.text: " 'Why, then,' said he to me, 'do you so look at me?'  " 'I am astonished,' I said, 'because you have chanced to be in my company in the same place; for I had not expected to see any man here.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 3:7
verses.text: '  "And he says to me, 'I am concerned about some of my household.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 3:8
verses.text: These are gone away from me; and therefore have I come to make personal search for them, if, perhaps, they shall make their appearance somewhere.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 3:9
verses.text: But why are you here?' said he to me.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 3:10
verses.text: " 'I delight,' said I, 'in such walks, where my attention is not distracted, for converse with myself is uninterrupted; and such places are most fit for philology.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 3:11
verses.text: '  " 'Are you, then, a philologian,' said he, 'but no lover of deeds or of truth? and do you not aim at being a practical man so much as being a sophist?'  " 'What greater work,' said I, 'could one accomplish than this, to show the reason which governs all, and having laid hold of it, and being mounted upon it, to look down on the errors of others, and their pursuits? But without philosophy and right reason, prudence would not be present to any man.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 3:12
verses.text: Wherefore it is necessary for every man to philosophize, and to esteem this the greatest and most honourable work; but other things only of second-rate or third-rate importance, though, indeed, if they be made to depend on philosophy, they are of moderate value, and worthy of acceptance; but deprived of it, and not accompanying it, they are vulgar and coarse to those who pursue them.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 3:13
verses.text: '  " 'Does philosophy, then, make happiness?' said he, interrupting.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 3:14
verses.text: " 'Assuredly,' I said, 'and it alone.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 3:15
verses.text: '  " 'What, then, is philosophy?' he says; 'and what is happiness? Pray tell me, unless something hinders you from saying.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 3:16
verses.text: '  " 'Philosophy, then,' said I, 'is the knowledge of that which really exists, and a clear perception of the truth; and happiness is the reward of such knowledge and wisdom.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 3:17
verses.text: '  " 'But what do you call God?' said he.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 3:18
verses.text: " 'That which always maintains the same nature, and in the same manner, and is the cause of all other things — that, indeed, is God.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 3:19
verses.text: ' So I answered him; and he listened to me with pleasure, and thus again interrogated me:—  " 'Is not knowledge a term common to different matters? For in arts of all kinds, he who knows any one of them is called a skilful man in the art of generalship, or of ruling, or of healing equally.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 3:20
verses.text: But in divine and human affairs it is not so.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 3:21
verses.text: Is there a knowledge which affords understanding of human and divine things, and then a thorough acquaintance with the divinity and the righteousness of them?'  " 'Assuredly,' I replied.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 3:22
verses.text: " 'What, then? Is it in the same way we know man and God, as we know music, and arithmetic, and astronomy, or any other similar branch?'  " 'By no means,' I replied.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 3:23
verses.text: " 'You have not answered me correctly, then,' he said; 'for some branches of knowledge come to us by learning, or by some employment, while of others we have knowledge by sight.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 3:24
verses.text: Now, if one were to tell you that there exists in India an animal with a nature unlike all others, but of such and such a kind, multiform and various, you would not know it before you saw it; but neither would you be competent to give any account of it, unless you should hear from one who had seen it.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 3:25
verses.text: '  " 'Certainly not,' I said.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 3:26
verses.text: " 'How then,' he said, 'should the philosophers judge correctly about God, or speak any truth, when they have no knowledge of Him, having neither seen Him at any time, nor heard Him?'  " 'But, father,' said I, 'the Deity cannot be seen merely by the eyes, as other living beings can, but is discernible to the mind alone, as Plato says; and I believe him.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 4:1
verses.text: Chapter 4 — The soul of itself cannot see God.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 4:2
verses.text: " 'Is there then,' says he, 'such and so great power in our mind? Or can a man not perceive by sense sooner? Will the mind of man see God at any time, if it is uninstructed by the Holy Spirit?'  " 'Plato indeed says,' replied I, 'that the mind's eye is of such a nature, and has been given for this end, that we may see that very Being when the mind is pure itself, who is the cause of all discerned by the mind, having no colour, no form, no greatness—nothing, indeed, which the bodily eye looks upon; but It is something of this sort, he goes on to say, that is beyond all essence, unutterable and inexplicable, but alone honourable and good, coming suddenly into souls well-dispositioned, on account of their affinity to and desire of seeing Him.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 4:3
verses.text: '  " 'What affinity, then,' replied he, 'is there between us and God? Is the soul also divine and immortal, and a part of that very regal mind? And even as that sees God, so also is it attainable by us to conceive of the Deity in our mind, and thence to become happy?'  " 'Assuredly,' I said.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 4:4
verses.text: " 'And do all the souls of all living beings comprehend Him?' he asked; 'or are the souls of men of one kind and the souls of horses and of asses of another kind?'  " 'No; but the souls which are in all are similar,' I answered.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 4:5
verses.text: " 'Then,' says he, 'shall both horses and asses see, or have they seen at some time or other, God?'  " 'No,' I said; 'for the majority of men will not, saving such as shall live justly, purified by righteousness, and by every other virtue.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 4:6
verses.text: '  " 'It is not, therefore,' said he, 'on account of his affinity, that a man sees God, nor because he has a mind, but because he is temperate and righteous?'  " 'Yes,' said I; 'and because he has that whereby he perceives God.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 4:7
verses.text: '  " 'What then? Do goats or sheep injure any one?'  " 'No one in any respect,' I said.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 4:8
verses.text: " 'Therefore these animals will see God according to your account,' says he.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 4:9
verses.text: " 'No; for their body being of such a nature, is an obstacle to them.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 4:10
verses.text: '  "He rejoined, 'If these animals could assume speech, be well assured that they would with greater reason ridicule our body; but let us now dismiss this subject, and let it be conceded to you as you say.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 4:11
verses.text: Tell me, however, this: Does the soul see God so long as it is in the body, or after it has been removed from it?'  " 'So long as it is in the form of a man, it is possible for it,' I continue, 'to attain to this by means of the mind; but especially when it has been set free from the body, and being apart by itself, it gets possession of that which it was wont continually and wholly to love.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 4:12
verses.text: '  " 'Does it remember this, then the sight of God, when it is again in the man?'  " 'It does not appear to me so,' I said.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 4:13
verses.text: " 'What, then, is the advantage to those who have seen God? or what has he who has seen more than he who has not seen, unless he remember this fact, that he has seen?'  " 'I cannot tell,' I answered.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 4:14
verses.text: " 'And what do those suffer who are judged to be unworthy of this spectacle?' said he.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 4:15
verses.text: " 'They are imprisoned in the bodies of certain wild beasts, and this is their punishment.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 4:16
verses.text: '  " 'Do they know, then, that it is for this reason they are in such forms, and that they have committed some sin?'  " 'I do not think so.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 4:17
verses.text: '  " 'Then these reap no advantage from their punishment, as it seems: moreover, I would say that they are not punished unless they are conscious of the punishment.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 4:18
verses.text: '  " 'No indeed.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 4:19
verses.text: '  " 'Therefore souls neither see God nor transmigrate into other bodies; for they would know that so they are punished, and they would be afraid to commit even the most trivial sin afterwards.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 4:20
verses.text: But that they can perceive that God exists, and that righteousness and piety are honourable, I also quite agree with you,' said he.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 4:21
verses.text: " 'You are right,' I replied.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 5:1
verses.text: Chapter 5 — The soul is not in its own nature immortal.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 5:2
verses.text: " 'These philosophers know nothing, then, about these things; for they cannot tell what a soul is.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 5:3
verses.text: '  " 'It does not appear so.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 5:4
verses.text: '  " 'Nor ought it to be called immortal; for if it is immortal, it is plainly unbegotten.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 5:5
verses.text: '  " 'It is both unbegotten and immortal, according to some who are styled Platonists.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 5:6
verses.text: '  " 'Do you say that the world is also unbegotten?'  " 'Some say so.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 5:7
verses.text: I do not, however, agree with them.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 5:8
verses.text: '  " 'You are right; for what reason has one for supposing that a body so solid, possessing resistance, composite, changeable, decaying, and renewed every day, has not arisen from some cause? But if the world is begotten, souls also are necessarily begotten; and perhaps at one time they were not in existence, for they were made on account of men and other living creatures, if you will say that they have been begotten wholly apart, and not along with their respective bodies.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 5:9
verses.text: '  " 'This seems to be correct.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 5:10
verses.text: '  " 'They are not, then, immortal?'  " 'No; since the world has appeared to us to be begotten.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 5:11
verses.text: '  " 'But I do not say, indeed, that all souls die; for that were truly a piece of good fortune to the evil.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 5:12
verses.text: What then? The souls of the pious remain in a better place, while those of the unjust and wicked are in a worse, waiting for the time of judgment.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 5:13
verses.text: Thus some which have appeared worthy of God never die; but others are punished so long as God wills them to exist and to be punished.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 5:14
verses.text: '  " 'Is what you say, then, of a like nature with that which Plato in Timaeus hints about the world, when he says that it is indeed subject to decay, inasmuch as it has been created, but that it will neither be dissolved nor meet with the fate of death on account of the will of God? Does it seem to you the very same can be said of the soul, and generally of all things? For those things which exist after God, or shall at any time exist, these have the nature of decay, and are such as may be blotted out and cease to exist; for God alone is unbegotten and incorruptible, and therefore He is God, but all other things after Him are created and corruptible.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 5:15
verses.text: For this reason souls both die and are punished: since, if they were unbegotten, they would neither sin, nor be filled with folly, nor be cowardly, and again ferocious; nor would they willingly transform into swine, and serpents, and dogs and it would not indeed be just to compel them, if they be unbegotten.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 5:16
verses.text: For that which is unbegotten is similar to, equal to, and the same with that which is unbegotten; and neither in power nor in honour should the one be preferred to the other, and hence there are not many things which are unbegotten: for if there were some difference between them, you would not discover the cause of the difference, though you searched for it; but after letting the mind ever wander to infinity, you would at length, wearied out, take your stand on one Unbegotten, and say that this is the Cause of all.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 5:17
verses.text: Did such escape the observation of Plato and Pythagoras, those wise men,'  I said, 'who have been as a wall and fortress of philosophy to us?'.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 6:1
verses.text: Chapter 6 — These things were unknown to Plato and other philosophers.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 6:2
verses.text: " 'It makes no matter to me,' said he, 'whether Plato or Pythagoras, or, in short, any other man held such opinions.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 6:3
verses.text: For the truth is so; and you would perceive it from this.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 6:4
verses.text: The soul assuredly is or has life.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 6:5
verses.text: If, then, it is life, it would cause something else, and not itself, to live, even as motion would move something else than itself.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 6:6
verses.text: Now, that the soul lives, no one would deny.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 6:7
verses.text: But if it lives, it lives not as being life, but as the partaker of life; but that which partakes of anything, is different from that of which it does partake.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 6:8
verses.text: Now the soul partakes of life, since God wills it to live.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 6:9
verses.text: Thus, then, it will not even partake of life when God does not will it to live.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 6:10
verses.text: For to live is not its attribute, as it is God's; but as a man does not live always, and the soul is not for ever conjoined with the body, since, whenever this harmony must be broken up, the soul leaves the body, and the man exists no longer; even so, whenever the soul must cease to exist, the spirit of life is removed from it, and there is no more soul, but it goes back to the place from whence it was taken.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 7:1
verses.text: Chapter 7 — The knowledge of truth to be sought from the prophets alone.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 7:2
verses.text: " 'Should any one, then, employ a teacher?' I say, 'or whence may any one be helped, if not even in them there is truth?'  " 'There existed, long before this time, certain men more ancient than all those who are esteemed philosophers, both righteous and beloved by God, who spoke by the Divine Spirit, and foretold events which would take place, and which are now taking place.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 7:3
verses.text: They are called prophets.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 7:4
verses.text: These alone both saw and announced the truth to men, neither reverencing nor fearing any man, not influenced by a desire for glory, but speaking those things alone which they saw and which they heard, being filled with the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 7:5
verses.text: Their writings are still extant, and he who has read them is very much helped in his knowledge of the beginning and end of things, and of those matters which the philosopher ought to know, provided he has believed them.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 7:6
verses.text: For they did not use demonstration in their treatises, seeing that they were witnesses to the truth above all demonstration, and worthy of belief; and those events which have happened, and those which are happening, compel you to assent to the utterances made by them, although, indeed, they were entitled to credit on account of the miracles which they performed, since they both glorified the Creator, the God and Father of all things, and proclaimed His Son, the Christ sent by Him: which, indeed, the false prophets, who are filled with the lying unclean spirit, neither have done nor do, but venture to work certain wonderful deeds for the purpose of astonishing men, and glorify the spirits and demons of error.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 7:7
verses.text: But pray that, above all things, the gates of light may be opened to you; for these things cannot be perceived or understood by all, but only by the man to whom God and His Christ have imparted wisdom.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 8:1
verses.text: Chapter 8 — Justin by his colloquy is kindled with love to Christ.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 8:2
verses.text: "When he had spoken these and many other things, which there is no time for mentioning at present, he went away, bidding me attend to them; and I have not seen him since.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 8:3
verses.text: But straightway a flame was kindled in my soul; and a love of the prophets, and of those men who are friends of Christ, possessed me; and whilst revolving his words in my mind, I found this philosophy alone to be safe and profitable.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 8:4
verses.text: Thus, and for this reason, I am a philosopher.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 8:5
verses.text: Moreover, I would wish that all, making a resolution similar to my own, do not keep themselves away from the words of the Saviour.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 8:6
verses.text: For they possess a terrible power in themselves, and are sufficient to inspire those who turn aside from the path of rectitude with awe; while the sweetest rest is afforded those who make a diligent practice of them.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 8:7
verses.text: If, then, you have any concern for yourself, and if you are eagerly looking for salvation, and if you believe in God, you may—since you are not indifferent to the matter — become acquainted with the Christ of God, and, after being initiated, live a happy life".

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 8:8
verses.text: When I had said this, my beloved friends those who were with Trypho laughed; but he, smiling, says, "I approve of your other remarks, and admire the eagerness with which you study divine things; but it were better for you still to abide in the philosophy of Plato, or of some other man, cultivating endurance, self-control, and moderation, rather than be deceived by false words, and follow the opinions of men of no reputation.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 8:9
verses.text: For if you remain in that mode of philosophy, and live blamelessly, a hope of a better destiny were left to you; but when you have forsaken God, and reposed confidence in man, what safety still awaits you? If, then, you are willing to listen to me (for I have already considered you a friend), first be circumcised, then observe what ordinances have been enacted with respect to the Sabbath, and the feasts, and the new moons of God; and, in a word, do all things which have been written in the law: and then perhaps you shall obtain mercy from God.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 8:10
verses.text: But Christ — if He has indeed been born, and exists anywhere—is unknown, and does not even know Himself, and has no power until Elias come to anoint Him, and make Him manifest to all.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 8:11
verses.text: And you, having accepted a groundless report, invent a Christ for yourselves, and for his sake are inconsiderately perishing".

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 9:1
verses.text: Chapter 9 — The Christians have not believed groundless stories.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 9:2
verses.text: "I excuse and forgive you, my friend," I said.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 9:3
verses.text: "For you know not what you say, but have been persuaded by teachers who do not understand the Scriptures; and you speak, like a diviner, whatever comes into your mind.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 9:4
verses.text: But if you are willing to listen to an account of Him, how we have not been deceived, and shall not cease to confess Him,—although men's reproaches be heaped upon us, although the most terrible tyrant compel us to deny Him,—I shall prove to you as you stand here that we have not believed empty fables, or words without any foundation but words filled with the Spirit of God, and big with power, and flourishing with grace".

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 9:5
verses.text: Then again those who were in his company laughed, and shouted in an unseemly manner.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 9:6
verses.text: Then I rose up and was about to leave; but he, taking hold of my garment, said I should not accomplish that until I had performed what I promised.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 9:7
verses.text: "Let not, then, your companions be so tumultuous, or behave so disgracefully," I said.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 9:8
verses.text: "But if they wish, let them listen in silence; or, if some better occupation prevent them, let them go away; while we, having retired to some spot, and resting there, may finish the discourse".

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 9:9
verses.text: It seemed good to Trypho that we should do so; and accordingly, having agreed upon it, we retired to the middle space of the Xystus.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 9:10
verses.text: Two of his friends, when they had ridiculed and made game of our zeal, went off.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 9:11
verses.text: And when we were come to that place, where there are stone seats on both sides, those with Trypho, having seated themselves on the one side, conversed with each other, some one of them having thrown in a remark about the war waged in Judaea.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 10:1
verses.text: Chapter 10 — Trypho blames the Christians for this alone—the non-observance of the law.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 10:2
verses.text: And when they ceased, I again addressed them thus:—  "Is there any other matter, my friends, in which we are blamed, than this, that we live not after the law, and are not circumcised in the flesh as your forefathers were, and do not observe sabbaths as you do? Are our lives and customs also slandered among you? And I ask this: have you also believed concerning us, that we eat men; and that after the feast, having extinguished the lights, we engage in promiscuous concubinage? Or do you condemn us in this alone, that we adhere to such tenets, and believe in an opinion, untrue, as you think?"  "This is what we are amazed at," said Trypho, "but those things about which the multitude speak are not worthy of belief; for they are most repugnant to human nature.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 10:3
verses.text: Moreover, I am aware that your precepts in the so-called Gospel are so wonderful and so great, that I suspect no one can keep them; for I have carefully read them.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 10:4
verses.text: But this is what we are most at a loss about: that you, professing to be pious, and supposing yourselves better than others, are not in any particular separated from them, and do not alter your mode of living from the nations, in that you observe no festivals or sabbaths, and do not have the rite of circumcision; and further, resting your hopes on a man that was crucified, you yet expect to obtain some good thing from God, while you do not obey His commandments.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 10:5
verses.text: Have you not read, that that soul shall be cut off from his people who shall not have been circumcised on the eighth day? And this has been ordained for strangers and for slaves equally.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 10:6
verses.text: But you, despising this covenant rashly, reject the consequent duties, and attempt to persuade yourselves that you know God, when, however, you perform none of those things which they do who fear God.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 10:7
verses.text: If, therefore, you can defend yourself on these points, and make it manifest in what way you hope for anything whatsoever, even though you do not observe the law, this we would very gladly hear from you, and we shall make other similar investigations".

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 11:1
verses.text: Chapter 11 — The law abrogated; the New Testament promised and given by God.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 11:2
verses.text: "There will be no other God, O Trypho, nor was there from eternity any other existing" (I thus addressed him), "but He who made and disposed all this universe.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 11:3
verses.text: Nor do we think that there is one God for us, another for you, but that He alone is God who led your fathers out from Egypt with a strong hand and a high arm.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 11:4
verses.text: Nor have we trusted in any other (for there is no other), but in Him in whom you also have trusted, the God of Abraham, and of Isaac, and of Jacob.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 11:5
verses.text: But we do not trust through Moses or through the law; for then we would do the same as yourselves.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 11:6
verses.text: But now—(for I have read that there shall be a final law, and a covenant, the chiefest  of all, which it is now incumbent on all men to observe, as many as are seeking after the inheritance of God.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 11:7
verses.text: For the law promulgated on Horeb is now old, and belongs to yourselves alone; but this is for all universally.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 11:8
verses.text: Now, law placed against law has abrogated that which is before it, and a covenant which comes after in like manner has put an end to the previous one; and an eternal and final law—namely, Christ — has been given to us, and the covenant is trustworthy, after which there shall be no law, no commandment, no ordinance.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 11:9
verses.text: Have you not read this which Isaiah says: 'Hearken unto Me, hearken unto Me, my people; and, ye kings, give ear unto Me: for a law shall go forth from Me, and My judgment shall be for a light to the nations.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 11:10
verses.text: My righteousness approaches swiftly, and My salvation shall go forth, and nations shall trust in Mine arm?' And by Jeremiah, concerning this same new covenant, He thus speaks: 'Behold, the days come, saith the Lord, that I will make a new covenant with the house of Israel and with the house of Judah; not according to the covenant which I made with their fathers, in the day that I took them by the hand, to bring them out of the land of Egypt').

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 11:11
verses.text: If, therefore, God proclaimed a new covenant which was to be instituted, and this for a light of the nations, we see and are persuaded that men approach God, leaving their idols and other unrighteousness, through the name of Him who was crucified, Jesus Christ, and abide by their confession even unto death, and maintain piety.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 11:12
verses.text: Moreover, by the works and by the attendant miracles, it is possible for all to understand that He is the new law, and the new covenant, and the expectation of those who out of every people wait for the good things of God.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 11:13
verses.text: For the true spiritual Israel, and descendants of Judah, Jacob, Isaac, and Abraham (who in uncircumcision was approved of and blessed by God on account of his faith, and called the father of many nations), are we who have been led to God through this crucified Christ, as shall be demonstrated while we proceed.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 12:1
verses.text: Chapter 12 — The Jews violate the eternal law, and interpret ill that of Moses.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 12:2
verses.text: I also adduced another passage in which Isaiah exclaims: " 'Hear My words, and your soul shall live; and I will make an everlasting covenant with you, even the sure mercies of David.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 12:3
verses.text: Behold, I have given Him for a witness to the people: nations which know not Thee shall call on Thee; peoples who know not Thee shall escape to Thee, because of thy God, the Holy One of Israel; for He has glorified Thee.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 12:4
verses.text: ' This same law you have despised, and His new holy covenant you have slighted; and now you neither receive it, nor repent of your evil deeds.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 12:5
verses.text: 'For your ears are closed, your eyes are blinded, and the heart is hardened,' Jeremiah has cried; yet not even then do you listen.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 12:6
verses.text: The Lawgiver is present, yet you do not see Him; to the poor the Gospel is preached, the blind see, yet you do not understand.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 12:7
verses.text: You have now need of a second circumcision, though you glory greatly in the flesh.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 12:8
verses.text: The new law requires you to keep perpetual sabbath, and you, because you are idle for one day, suppose you are pious, not discerning why this has been commanded you: and if you eat unleavened bread, you say the will of God has been fulfilled.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 12:9
verses.text: The Lord our God does not take pleasure in such observances: if there is any perjured person or a thief among you, let him cease to be so; if any adulterer, let him repent; then he has kept the sweet and true sabbaths of God.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 12:10
verses.text: If any one has impure hands, let him wash and be pure.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 13:1
verses.text: Chapter 13 — Isaiah teaches that sins are forgiven through Christ's blood.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 13:2
verses.text: "For Isaiah did not send you to a bath, there to wash away murder and other sins, which not even all the water of the sea were sufficient to purge; but, as might have been expected, this was that saving bath of the olden time which followed those who repented, and who no longer were purified by the blood of goats and of sheep, or by the ashes of an heifer, or by the offerings of fine flour, but by faith through the blood of Christ, and through His death, who died for this very reason, as Isaiah himself said, when he spake thus: 'The Lord shall make bare His holy arm in the eyes of all the nations, and all the nations and the ends of the earth shall see the salvation of God.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 13:3
verses.text: Depart ye, depart ye, depart ye, go ye out from thence, and touch no unclean thing; go ye out of the midst of her, be ye clean that bear the vessels of the Lord, for ye go not with haste.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 13:4
verses.text: For the Lord shall go before you; and the Lord, the God of Israel, shall gather you together.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 13:5
verses.text: Behold, my servant shall deal prudently; and He shall be exalted, and be greatly glorified.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 13:6
verses.text: As many were astonished at Thee, so Thy form and Thy glory shall be marred more than men.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 13:7
verses.text: So shall many nations be astonished at Him, and the kings shall shut their mouths; for that which had not been told them concerning Him shall they see, and that which they had not heard shall they consider.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 13:8
verses.text: Lord,  who hath believed our report? and to whom is the arm of the Lord revealed? We have announced Him as a child before Him, as a root in a dry ground.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 13:9
verses.text: He hath no form or comeliness, and when we saw Him He had no form or beauty; but His form is dishonoured, and fails more than the sons of men.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 13:10
verses.text: He is a man in affliction, and acquainted with bearing sickness, because His face has been turned away; He was despised, and we esteemed Him not.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 13:11
verses.text: He bears our sins, and is distressed for us; and we esteemed Him to be in toil and in affliction, and in evil treatment.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 13:12
verses.text: But He was wounded for our transgressions, He was bruised for our iniquities; the chastisement of our peace was upon Him.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 13:13
verses.text: With His stripes we are healed.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 13:14
verses.text: All we, like sheep, have gone astray.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 13:15
verses.text: Every man has turned to his own way; and the Lord laid on Him our iniquities, and by reason of His oppression He opens not His mouth.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 13:16
verses.text: He was brought as a sheep to the slaughter; and as a lamb before her shearer is dumb, so He openeth not His mouth.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 13:17
verses.text: In His humiliation His judgment was taken away.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 13:18
verses.text: And who shall declare His generation? For His life is taken from the earth.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 13:19
verses.text: Because of the transgressions of my people He came unto death.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 13:20
verses.text: And I will give the wicked for His grave, and the rich for His death, because He committed no iniquity, and deceit was not found in His mouth.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 13:21
verses.text: And the Lord wills to purify Him from affliction.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 13:22
verses.text: If he has been given for sin, your soul shall see a long-lived seed.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 13:23
verses.text: And the Lord wills to take His soul away from trouble, to show Him light, and to form Him in understanding, to justify the righteous One who serves many well.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 13:24
verses.text: And He shall bear our sins; therefore He shall inherit many, and shall divide the spoil of the strong, because His soul was delivered to death; and He was numbered with the transgressors, and He bare the sins of many, and was delivered for their transgression.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 13:25
verses.text: Sing, O barren, who bearest not; break forth and cry aloud, thou who dost not travail in pain: for more are the children of the desolate than the children of the married wife.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 13:26
verses.text: For the Lord said, Enlarge the place of thy tent and of thy curtains; fix them, spare not, lengthen thy cords, and strengthen thy stakes; stretch forth to thy right and thy left; and thy seed shall inherit the Gentiles, and thou shalt make the desolate cities to be inherited.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 13:27
verses.text: Fear not because thou art ashamed, neither be thou confounded because thou hast been reproached; for thou shalt forget everlasting shame, and shalt not remember the reproach of thy widowhood, because the Lord has made a name for Himself, and He who has redeemed thee shall be called through the whole earth the God of Israel.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 13:28
verses.text: The Lord has called thee as a woman forsaken and grieved in spirit, as a woman hated from her youth.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 14:1
verses.text: Chapter 14 — Righteousness is not placed in Jewish rites, but in the conversion of the heart given in baptism by Christ.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 14:2
verses.text: "By reason, therefore, of this laver of repentance and knowledge of God, which has been ordained on account of the transgression of God's people, as Isaiah cries, we have believed, and testify that that very baptism which he announced is alone able to purify those who have repented; and this is the water of life.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 14:3
verses.text: But the cisterns which you have dug for yourselves are broken and profitless to you.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 14:4
verses.text: For what is the use of that baptism which cleanses the flesh and body alone? Baptize the soul from wrath and from covetousness, from envy, and from hatred; and, lo! the body is pure.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 14:5
verses.text: For this is the symbolic significance of unleavened bread, that you do not commit the old deeds of wicked leaven.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 14:6
verses.text: But you have understood all things in a carnal sense, and you suppose it to be piety if you do such things, while your souls are filled with deceit, and, in short, with every wickedness.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 14:7
verses.text: Accordingly, also, after the seven days of eating unleavened bread, God commanded them to mingle new leaven, that is, the performance of other works, and not the imitation of the old and evil works.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 14:8
verses.text: And because this is what this new Lawgiver demands of you, I shall again refer to the words which have been quoted by me, and to others also which have been passed over.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 14:9
verses.text: They are related by Isaiah to the following effect: 'Hearken to me, and your soul shall live; and I will make with you an everlasting covenant, even the sure mercies of David.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 14:10
verses.text: Behold, I have given Him for a witness to the people, a leader and commander to the nations.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 14:11
verses.text: Nations which know not Thee shall call on Thee; and peoples who know not Thee shall escape unto Thee, because of Thy God, the Holy One of Israel, for He has glorified Thee.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 14:12
verses.text: Seek ye God; and when you find Him, call on Him, so long as He may be nigh you.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 14:13
verses.text: Let the wicked forsake his ways, and the unrighteous man his thoughts; and let him return unto the Lord, and he will obtain mercy, because He will abundantly pardon your sins.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 14:14
verses.text: For my thoughts are not as your thoughts, neither are my ways as your ways; but as far removed as the heavens are from the earth, so far is my way removed from your way, and your thoughts from my thoughts.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 14:15
verses.text: For as the snow or the rain descends from heaven, and shall not return till it waters the earth, and makes it bring forth and bud, and gives seed to the sower and bread for food, so shall My word be that goeth forth out of My mouth: it shall not return until it shall have accomplished all that I desired, and I shall make My commandments prosperous.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 14:16
verses.text: For ye shall go out with joy, and be taught with gladness.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 14:17
verses.text: For the mountains and the hills shall leap while they expect you, and all the trees of the fields shall applaud with their branches: and instead of the thorn shall come up the cypress, and instead of the brier shall come up the myrtle.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 14:18
verses.text: And the Lord shall be for a name, and for an everlasting sign, and He shall not fail!' Of these and such like words written by the prophets, O Trypho," said I, "some have reference to the first advent of Christ, in which He is preached as inglorious, obscure, and of mortal appearance: but others had reference to His second advent, when He shall appear in glory and above the clouds; and your nation shall see and know Him whom they have pierced, as Hosea, one of the twelve prophets, and Daniel, foretold.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 15:1
verses.text: Chapter 15 — In what the true fasting consists.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 15:2
verses.text: "Learn, therefore, to keep the true fast of God, as Isaiah says, that you may please God.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 15:3
verses.text: Isaiah has cried thus: 'Shout vehemently, and do not spare: lift up thy voice as with a trumpet, and show My people their transgressions, and the house of Jacob their sins.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 15:4
verses.text: They seek Me from day to day, and desire to know My ways, as a nation that did righteousness, and forsook not the judgment of God.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 15:5
verses.text: They ask of Me now righteous judgment, and desire to draw near to God, saying, Wherefore have we fasted, and Thou seest not? and afflicted our souls, and Thou hast not known? Because in the days of your fasting you find your own pleasure, and oppress all those who are subject to you.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 15:6
verses.text: Behold, ye fast for strifes and debates, and smite the humble with your fists.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 15:7
verses.text: Why do ye fast for Me, as to-day, so that your voice is heard aloud? This is not the fast which I have chosen, the day in which a man shall afflict his soul.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 15:8
verses.text: And not even if you bend your neck like a ring, or clothe yourself in sackcloth and ashes, shall you call this a fast, and a day acceptable to the Lord.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 15:9
verses.text: This is not the fast which I have chosen, saith the Lord; but loose every unrighteous bond, dissolve the terms of wrongous covenants, let the oppressed go free, and avoid every iniquitous contract.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 15:10
verses.text: Deal thy bread to the hungry, and lead the homeless poor under thy dwelling; if thou seest the naked, clothe him; and do not hide thyself from thine own flesh.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 15:11
verses.text: Then shall thy light break forth as the morning, and thy garments shall rise up quickly: and thy righteousness shall go before thee, and the glory of God shall envelope thee.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 15:12
verses.text: Then shalt thou cry, and the Lord shall hear thee: while thou art speaking, He will say, Behold, I am here.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 15:13
verses.text: And if thou take away from thee the yoke, and the stretching out of the hand, and the word of murmuring; and shalt give heartily thy bread to the hungry, and shalt satisfy the afflicted soul; then shall thy light arise in the darkness, and thy darkness shall be as the noon-day: and thy God shall be with thee continually, and thou shalt be satisfied according as thy soul desireth, and thy bones shall become fat, and shall be as a watered garden, and as a fountain of water, or as a land where water fails not.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 15:14
verses.text: ' 'Circumcise, therefore, the foreskin of your heart,' as the words of God in all these passages demand".

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 16:1
verses.text: Chapter 16 — Circumcision given as a sign, that the Jews might be driven away for their evil deeds done to Christ and the Christians.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 16:2
verses.text: "And God himself proclaimed by Moses, speaking thus: 'And circumcise the hardness of your hearts, and no longer stiffen the neck.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 16:3
verses.text: For the Lord your God is both Lord of lords, and a great, mighty, and terrible God, who regardeth not persons, and taketh not rewards.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 16:4
verses.text: ' And in Leviticus: 'Because they have transgressed against Me, and despised Me, and because they have walked contrary to Me, I also walked contrary to them, and I shall cut them off in the land of their enemies.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 16:5
verses.text: Then shall their uncircumcised heart be turned.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 16:6
verses.text: For the circumcision according to the flesh, which is from Abraham, was given for a sign; that you may be separated from other nations, and from us; and that you alone may suffer that which you now justly suffer; and that your land may be desolate, and your cities burned with fire; and that strangers may eat your fruit in your presence, and not one of you may go up to Jerusalem.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 16:7
verses.text: ' For you are not recognised among the rest of men by any other mark than your fleshly circumcision.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 16:8
verses.text: For none of you, I suppose, will venture to say that God neither did nor does foresee the events, which are future, nor foreordained his deserts for each one.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 16:9
verses.text: Accordingly, these things have happened to you in fairness and justice, for you have slain the Just One, and His prophets before Him; and now you reject those who hope in Him, and in Him who sent Him—God the Almighty and Maker of all things — cursing in your synagogues those that believe on Christ.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 16:10
verses.text: For you have not the power to lay hands upon us, on account of those who now have the mastery.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 16:11
verses.text: But as often as you could, you did so.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 16:12
verses.text: Wherefore God, by Isaiah, calls to you, saying, 'Behold how the righteous man perished, and no one regards it.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 16:13
verses.text: For the righteous man is taken away from before iniquity.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 16:14
verses.text: His grave shall be in peace, he is taken away from the midst.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 16:15
verses.text: Draw near hither, ye lawless children, seed of the adulterers, and children of the whore.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 16:16
verses.text: Against whom have you sported yourselves, and against whom have you opened the mouth, and against whom have you loosened the tongue?'.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 17:1
verses.text: Chapter 17 — The Jews sent persons through the whole earth to spread calumnies on Christians.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 17:2
verses.text: "For other nations have not inflicted on us and on Christ this wrong to such an extent as you have, who in very deed are the authors of the wicked prejudice against the Just One, and us who hold by Him.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 17:3
verses.text: For after that you had crucified Him, the only blameless and righteous Man,— through whose stripes those who approach the Father by Him are healed, — when you knew that He had risen from the dead and ascended to heaven, as the prophets foretold He would, you not only did not repent of the wickedness which you had committed, but at that time you selected and sent out from Jerusalem chosen men through all the land to tell that the godless heresy of the Christians had sprung up, and to publish those things which all they who knew us not speak against us.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 17:4
verses.text: So that you are the cause not only of your own unrighteousness, but in fact of that of all other men.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 17:5
verses.text: And Isaiah cries justly: 'By reason of you, My name is blasphemed among the Gentiles.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 17:6
verses.text: ' And: 'Woe unto their soul! because they have devised an evil device against themselves, saying, Let us bind the righteous, for he is distasteful to us.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 17:7
verses.text: Therefore they shall eat the fruit of their doings.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 17:8
verses.text: Woe unto the wicked! evil shall be rendered to him according to the works of his hands.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 17:9
verses.text: ' And again, in other words: 'Woe unto them that draw their iniquity as with a long cord, and their transgressions as with the harness of a heifer's yoke: who say, Let his speed come near; and let the counsel of the Holy One of Israel come, that we may know it.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 17:10
verses.text: Woe unto them that call evil good, and good evil; that put light for darkness, and darkness for light; that put bitter for sweet, and sweet for bitter!' Accordingly, you displayed great zeal in publishing throughout all the land bitter and dark and unjust things against the only blameless and righteous Light sent by God.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 17:11
verses.text: For He appeared distasteful to you when He cried among you, 'It is written, My house is the house of prayer; but ye have made it a den of thieves!' He overthrew also the tables of the money-changers in the temple, and exclaimed, 'Woe unto you, Scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites! because ye pay tithe of mint and rue, but do not observe the love of God and justice.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 17:12
verses.text: Ye whited sepulchres! appearing beautiful outward, but are within full of dead men's bones.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 17:13
verses.text: ' And to the Scribes, 'Woe unto you, Scribes! for ye have the keys, and ye do not enter in yourselves, and them that are entering in ye hinder; ye blind guides!'.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 18:1
verses.text: Chapter 18 — Christians would observe the law, if they did not know why it was instituted.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 18:2
verses.text: "For since you have read, O Trypho, as you yourself admitted, the doctrines taught by our Saviour, I do not think that I have done foolishly in adding some short utterances of His to the prophetic statements.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 18:3
verses.text: Wash therefore, and be now clean, and put away iniquity from your souls, as God bids you be washed in this laver, and be circumcised with the true circumcision.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 18:4
verses.text: For we too would observe the fleshly circumcision, and the Sabbaths, and in short all the feasts, if we did not know for what reason they were enjoined you,—namely, on account of your transgressions and the hardness of your hearts.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 18:5
verses.text: For if we patiently endure all things contrived against us by wicked men and demons, so that even amid cruelties unutterable, death and torments, we pray for mercy to those who inflict such things upon us, and do not wish to give the least retort to any one, even as the new Lawgiver commanded us: how is it, Trypho, that we would not observe those rites which do not harm us, — I speak of fleshly circumcision, and Sabbaths, and feasts?.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 19:1
verses.text: Chapter 19 — Circumcision unknown before Abraham.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 19:2
verses.text: The law was given by Moses on account of the hardness of their hearts.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 19:3
verses.text: "It is this about which we are at a loss, and with reason, because, while you endure such things, you do not observe all the other customs which we are now discussing".

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 19:4
verses.text: "This circumcision is not, however, necessary for all men, but for you alone, in order that, as I have already said, you may suffer these things which you now justly suffer.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 19:5
verses.text: Nor do we receive that useless baptism of cisterns, for it has nothing to do with this baptism of life.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 19:6
verses.text: Wherefore also God has announced that you have forsaken Him, the living fountain, and digged for yourselves broken cisterns which can hold no water.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 19:7
verses.text: Even you, who are the circumcised according to the flesh, have need of our circumcision; but we, having the latter, do not require the former.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 19:8
verses.text: For if it were necessary, as you suppose, God  would not have made Adam uncircumcised; would not have had respect to the gifts of Abel when, being uncircumcised, he offered sacrifice and would not have been pleased with the uncircumcision of Enoch, who was not found, because God had translated him.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 19:9
verses.text: Lot, being uncircumcised, was saved from Sodom, the angels themselves and the Lord sending him out.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 19:10
verses.text: Noah was the beginning of our race; yet, uncircumcised, along with his children he went into the ark.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 19:11
verses.text: Melchizedek, the priest of the Most High, was uncircumcised; to whom also Abraham the first who received circumcision after the flesh, gave tithes, and he blessed him: after whose order God declared, by the mouth of David, that He would establish the everlasting priest.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 19:12
verses.text: Therefore to you alone this circumcision was necessary, in order that the people may be no people, and the nation no nation; as also Hosea, one of the twelve prophets, declares.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 19:13
verses.text: Moreover, all those righteous men already mentioned, though they kept no Sabbaths, were pleasing to God; and after them Abraham with all his descendants until Moses, under whom your nation appeared unrighteous and ungrateful to God, making a calf in the wilderness: wherefore God, accommodating Himself to that nation, enjoined them also to offer sacrifices, as if to His name, in order that you might not serve idols.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 19:14
verses.text: Which precept, however, you have not observed; nay, you sacrificed your children to demons.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 19:15
verses.text: And you were commanded to keep Sabbaths, that you might retain the memorial of God.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 19:16
verses.text: For His word makes this announcement, saying, 'That ye may know that I am God who redeemed you.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 20:1
verses.text: Chapter 20 — Why choice of meats was prescribed.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 20:2
verses.text: "Moreover, you were commanded to abstain from certain kinds of food, in order that you might keep God before your eyes while you ate and drank, seeing that you were prone and very ready to depart from His knowledge, as Moses also affirms: 'The people ate and drank, and rose up to play.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 20:3
verses.text: ' And again: 'Jacob ate, and was satisfied, and waxed fat; and he who was beloved kicked: he waxed fat, he grew thick, he was enlarged, and he forsook God who had made him.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 20:4
verses.text: ' For it was told you by Moses in the book of Genesis, that God granted to Noah, being a just man, to eat of every animal, but not of flesh with the blood, which is dead".

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 20:5
verses.text: And as he was ready to say, "as the green herbs," I anticipated him: "Why do you not receive this statement, 'as the green herbs,' in the sense in which it was given by God, to wit, that just as God has granted the herbs for sustenance to man, even so has He given the animals for the diet of flesh? But, you say, a distinction was laid down thereafter to Noah, because we do not eat certain herbs.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 20:6
verses.text: As you interpret it, the thing is incredible.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 20:7
verses.text: And first I shall not occupy myself with this, though able to say and to hold that every vegetable is food, and fit to be eaten.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 20:8
verses.text: But although we discriminate between green herbs, not eating all, we refrain from eating some, not because they are common or unclean, but because they are bitter, or deadly, or thorny.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 20:9
verses.text: But we lay hands on and take of all herbs which are sweet, very nourishing and good, whether they are marine or land plants.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 20:10
verses.text: Thus also God by the mouth of Moses commanded you to abstain from unclean and improper and violent animals: when, moreover, though you were eating manna in the desert, and were seeing all those wondrous acts wrought for you by God, you made and worshipped the golden calf.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 20:11
verses.text: Hence he cries continually, and justly, 'They are foolish children, in whom is no faith.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 21:1
verses.text: Chapter 21 — Sabbaths were instituted on account of the people's sins, and not for a work of righteousness.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 21:2
verses.text: "Moreover, that God enjoined you to keep the Sabbath, and impose on you other precepts for a sign, as I have already said, on account of your unrighteousness, and that of your fathers,—as He declares that for the sake of the nations, lest His name be profaned among them, therefore He permitted some of you to remain alive,—these words of His can prove to you: they are narrated by Ezekiel thus: 'I am the Lord your God; walk in My statutes, and keep My judgments, and take no part in the customs of Egypt; and hallow My Sabbaths; and they shall be a sign between Me and you, that ye may know that I am the Lord your God.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 21:3
verses.text: Notwithstanding ye rebelled against Me, and your children walked not in My statutes, neither kept My judgments to do them: which if a man do, he shall live in them.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 21:4
verses.text: But they polluted My Sabbaths.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 21:5
verses.text: And I said that I would pour out My fury upon them in the wilderness, to accomplish My anger upon them; yet I did it not; that My name might not be altogether profaned in the sight of the heathen.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 21:6
verses.text: I led them out before their eyes, and  I lifted up Mine hand unto them in the wilderness, that I would scatter them among the heathen, and disperse them through the countries; because they had not executed My judgments, but had despised My statutes, and polluted My Sabbaths, and their eyes were after the devices of their fathers.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 21:7
verses.text: Wherefore I gave them also statutes which were not good, and judgments whereby they shall not live.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 21:8
verses.text: And I shall pollute them in their own gifts, that I may destroy all that openeth the womb, when I pass through them.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 22:1
verses.text: Chapter 22 — So also were sacrifices and oblations.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 22:2
verses.text: "And that you may learn that it was for the sins of your own nation, and for their idolatries and not because there was any necessity for such sacrifices, that they were likewise enjoined, listen to the manner in which He speaks of these by Amos, one of the twelve, saying: 'Woe unto you that desire the day of the Lord! to what end is this day of the Lord for you? It is darkness and not light, as when a man flees from the face of a lion, and a bear meets him; and he goes into his house, and leans his hands against the wall, and the serpent bites him.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 22:3
verses.text: Shall not the day of the Lord be darkness and not light, even very dark, and no brightness in it? I have hated, I have despised your feast-days, and I will not smell in your solemn assemblies: wherefore, though ye offer Me your burnt-offerings and sacrifices, I will not accept them; neither will I regard the peace-offerings of your presence.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 22:4
verses.text: Take thou away from Me the multitude of thy songs and psalms; I will not hear thine instruments.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 22:5
verses.text: But let judgment be rolled down as water, and righteousness as an impassable torrent.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 22:6
verses.text: Have ye offered unto Me victims and sacrifices in the wilderness, O house of Israel? saith the Lord.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 22:7
verses.text: And have ye taken up the tabernacle of Moloch, and the star of your god Raphan, the figures which ye made for yourselves? And I will carry you away beyond Damascus, saith the Lord, whose name is the Almighty God.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 22:8
verses.text: Woe to them that are at ease in Zion, and trust in the mountain of Samaria: those who are named among the chiefs have plucked away the first-fruits of the nations: the house of Israel have entered for themselves.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 22:9
verses.text: Pass all of you unto Calneh, and see; and from thence go ye unto Hamath the great, and go down thence to Gath of the strangers, the noblest of all these kingdoms, if their boundaries are greater than your boundaries.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 22:10
verses.text: Ye who come to the evil day, who are approaching, and who hold to false Sabbaths; who lie on beds of ivory, and are at ease upon their couches; who eat the lambs out of the flock, and the sucking calves out of the midst of the herd; who applaud at the sound of the musical instruments; they reckon them as stable, and not as fleeting, who drink wine in bowls, and anoint themselves with the chief ointments, but they are not grieved for the affliction of Joseph.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 22:11
verses.text: Wherefore now they shall be captives, among the first of the nobles who are carried away; and the house of evil-doers shall be removed, and the neighing of horses shall be taken away from Ephraim.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 22:12
verses.text: ' And again by Jeremiah: 'Collect your flesh, and sacrifices, and eat: for concerning neither sacrifices nor libations did I command your fathers in the day in which I took them by the hand to lead them out of Egypt.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 22:13
verses.text: ' And again by David, in the forty-ninth Psalm, He thus said: 'The God of gods, the Lord hath spoken, and called the earth, from the rising of the sun unto the going down thereof.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 22:14
verses.text: Out of Zion is the perfection of His beauty.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 22:15
verses.text: God, even our God, shall come openly, and shall not keep silence.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 22:16
verses.text: Fire shall burn before Him, and it shall be very tempestuous round about Him.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 22:17
verses.text: He shall call to the heavens above, and to the earth, that He may judge His people.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 22:18
verses.text: Assemble to Him His saints; those that have made a covenant with Him by sacrifices.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 22:19
verses.text: And the heavens shall declare His righteousness, for God is judge.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 22:20
verses.text: Hear, O My people, and I will speak to thee; O Israel, and I will testify to thee, I am God, even thy God.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 22:21
verses.text: I will not reprove thee for thy sacrifices; thy burnt-offerings are continually before me.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 22:22
verses.text: I will take no bullocks out of thy house, nor he-goats out of thy folds: for all the beasts of the field are Mine, the herds and the oxen on the mountains.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 22:23
verses.text: I know all the fowls of the heavens, and the beauty of the field is Mine.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 22:24
verses.text: If I were hungry, I would not tell thee; for the world is Mine, and the fulness thereof.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 22:25
verses.text: Will I eat the flesh of bulls, or drink the blood of goats? Offer unto God the sacrifice of praise, and pay thy vows unto the Most High, and call upon Me in the day of trouble, and I will deliver thee, and thou shalt glorify Me.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 22:26
verses.text: But unto the wicked God saith, What hast thou to do to declare My statutes, and to take My covenant into thy mouth? But thou hast hated instruction, and cast My words behind thee.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 22:27
verses.text: When thou sawest a thief, thou consentedst with him; and hast been partaker with the adulterer.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 22:28
verses.text: Thy mouth has framed evil, and thy tongue has enfolded deceit.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 22:29
verses.text: Thou sittest and speakest against thy brother; thou slanderest thine own mother's son.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 22:30
verses.text: These things hast thou done, and I kept silence; thou thoughtest that I would be like thyself in wickedness.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 22:31
verses.text: I will reprove thee, and set thy sins in order before thine eyes.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 22:32
verses.text: Now consider this, ye that forget God, lest He tear you in pieces, and there be none to deliver.

verses.name: Justin Martyr: Dialogue with Trypho 22:33
